prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Sensitivity Requirements: We aim to achieve a N2D+(3-2) line sensitivity of 40 mJy per 2" beam per 0.16 km/s, which is designed to detect N2D+(3-2) emission from ~solar mass cores (see Scientific Justification).

The scientific motivation for this set-up was described above. Baseband-1 is set for N2D+(3-2) (231.32 GHz) with bandwidth 58.594MHz (76km/s) and resolution 0.046km/s. Baseband-2 is set for continuum at 231 GHz with bandwidth 1875MHz (2434km/s) and resolution 1.465 km/s with a goal of measuring the continuum flux and also searching for any protostellar outflows emitting CO(2-1). Baseband-3 is set for C18O(2-1) (219.56 GHz) with bandwidth 58.594 MHz (80 km/s) and resolution 0.048 km/s. Baseband-4 is set for 4 lines: DCO+(v=0,3-2), CH3OH (vt=0, 5(1,4)-4(2,2)), SiO(v=0, 5-4), DCN(v=0, 3-2), all with 58.594 MHz (81 km/s) bandwidth and resolution 0.195 km/s.

We request a compact configuration yielding angular resolution of ~2" for efficient mosaicing. We have divided the entire field of view into 5 strips, each about 1' wide and 5.3' long and containing ~150 pointings. This covers the large majority of the HST-mapped FOV, especially covering the dense gas which is somewhat centrally concentrated. Since we desire to detect all structures on scales up to several arcminutes, we request the ACA.

The scientific motivation for the spectral set-up was described in the Scientific Justificationl. The relatively high data rate results from the focus on gas kinematics in all spectral windows. Also, we wish to have the same spectral set-up as the already approved Cycle 2 project studying similar cores in an IRDC.
Sensitivity Requirements: See science goal one.
Correlator set-up: see science goal one.
Spatial requirements: see science goal one.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to study the kinematics of gas in a massive protocluster, G286.21+0.17, that is the target of an ongoing HST study of proper motion kinematics of young stellar objects. The unique comparisons that will be possible between ALMA-derived gas kinematics and HST-derived young stellar object (YSO) kinematics will help answer fundamental questions associated with massive star cluster formation, such as: "What is the nature of spatial and kinematic substructure in gas and YSOs and how do they compare?" "What is the level of turbulent velocity dispersion of gas in comparison to stellar motions, and the implications for global support of the protocluster and thus the timescale of star cluster formation?". The ALMA observations will identify populations of dense cores in different tracers, which can be compared in terms of their spatial, kinematic and core mass function properties, to similar approved Cycle 2 observations of cores in a massive IRDC, thus probing different evolutionary stages of the massive star cluster formation process.
